awd_titl_txt: Columbia University/ R/V Marcus G. Langseth-  Oceanographic Instrumentation
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is for funding the purchase of new instrumentation (CTD system) for the R/V Marcus Langseth, a 235’ Global seismic vessel with general oceanographic capabilities. The vessel is owned by Columbia University and operated by Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University under a cooperative agreement with NSF. The Langseth is unique in the U.S. Academic Research Fleet in that it provides a combination of capabilities for imaging the oceans, the seafloor, and the solid earth beneath the sea. It is the only vessel in the world dedicated to academic research that can conduct 3D seismic surveys as well as extended offset 2D surveys. Lately, the vessel is utilized also as a general oceanographic vessel with a demand for extended hydrographic surveys that provide information on the vertical structure of the water column (temperature and salinity as function of depth) using CTDs. This award provides funds for one CTD system for use by the vessel during these surveys. The system would consist of electronics and 30 water sampling bottles (24 operational and 6 spares) as well as the required custom-built frame, interconnecting cables, and ancillary hardware.

The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 23-525). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance, and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or other organization access to well-maintained, high-quality, calibrated instruments for their research. It ensures the collection of high-quality oceanographic data in support of science, reduces the cost of that research, and expands the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The focus of our Ocean Instrumentation proposal was to obtain new critical water sampling equipment that will augment the services R/V Marcus G. Langseth (Langseth) can provide to the academic community.  These commonly used water sampling systems called Conductivity, Temperature and Depth sensors (or CTDs) allow samples looking at ocean water properties to be collected from different depths in bottles throughout the water column typically at depths between 100's to 1000's of meters. The sample bottles can be activated by sending signals down the wire from the ship above to tell the bottles when to open at a particular depth.

Since 2022, the Langseth has been taking onmore general oceanographic work and has had to borrow this equipment from other Academic Research Fleet (ARF) ships. The open Langseth starboard side deck and A-frame are very well suited for CTD operations. Langseth has the other infrastructure installed including a large winch that constains 10,000m of wire, other handling equipment and onboard laboratories.

As part of the award, all the sample bottles and sensors have undergone calibration and testing for this new 24-bottle SeaBird Scientific CTD system  and then system was put together in our labs at LDEO. Two new CTD frames that hold the sample bottles were also constructed based on a  fleet-wide common design.

This new CTD equipment will now be available for the Langseth which greatly simplifies logistics and planning for future projects. This equipment will also serve as a shared fleetwise  resource should other operators need equipment when not in use. Looking ahead into 2025 and beyond, future science projects with water sampling and a CTD requirements will be better served by having this equipment available and will allow for more opportunities to support the science community.
